div.head: RUSSIAN REFORM. CONFERENCE TO BE HELD.

div.p: The Constitutional Conservative Party, which is now being termed in Russia, includes 7 members of the Council of the Empire besides Senators and prominent Government officials. The party is countenanced by M. Bnliguine and is issuing several thousand invitations throughout Russia for a Conference to be held in St. Petersburg on tho subject of reform. A scheme for the composition of a representative Assembly has already boon drawn up. (R)

div.p: The recently appointed committee formed for the purpose of repressing the "white slave traffic" in Egypt will meet at the Alexandria Gouvomorat tomorrow at 5 p.m. in order to discuss certain proposals, and to elect an executive committee from their number. H.E. the Governor will preside.

div.head: The Police and Dogs.—
div.p: A correspondent writes: The following incident took at Ibrahimieh on Friday last, on which day the police cart was there both morning and afternoon. An Englishman was driving with an Arab by his side while two other men, one a Greek, the other an Arab, were in the cart An invalid German lady resident was standing at the door of her house watching her little dog, who was being given a short run and within call, when the dog was lassoed by the two men and put in tho cart. The lady cried out, and although unable to do much, tried to stop the cart and recover her pet. The driver whipped up his horses and she was thrown the ground. However, she got up and bold the bridle of one horse. Again the driver used his whip and the plucky lady was hit across the hands. Ultimately she succeeded in recovering the dog. The animal had been fully under her control, and the action of the police was quite unjustifiable."

div.head: LORD CROMER'S REPORT. PUBLISHED IN LONDON. THE CAPITULATIONS. ATTITUDE OF KHEDIVE
div.p: Lord Cromer's annual Report on Egypt and the Sudan, which has been published, is of great' interest. He dwells on the necessity of modifying the regime of the Capitulations, more especially in the direction of devising an improved scheme for legislation where Europeans are concerned.

He alludes to the rapid growth of the Sudan revenue, and points out that, exclusive of capital expenditure, the cost of the Sudan to Egypt in 1904 only amounted to LE. 27,000. He states that the attitude of the Khedive has contributed to establish the most friendly relations between tho British and Egyptian portions of the Administration, and speaks in complimentary terms of tho action of the Legislative Council and Assembly. (Reuter.)

div.p: Up to date over half of the Egyptian pilgrims have returned to their homes from the Holy Places, and the remainder are expected to arrive shortly at Suez from Tor. div.head: LOCAL GERMAN ENTERPRISE
div.p: Next season the Hamburg-Amerika Line intend developing their Mediterranean system by running regular steamers between Naples and Alexandria. The same company is building a magnificent sanatorium-yacht at Hamburg. The boat is to be called the ''Furst Bismarck," the liner of that name having been sold to the Russians. The steamer will visit Alexandria several times daring the coarse of the season. She will carry a staff of ten or twelve physicians, under the direction of Prof. Schweninger, medical adviser and confidante of Prince Bismarck. The company may open some hotels in Egypt, but on this point nothing has yet been decided. It is however certain that their offices near the Grand Continental Hotel, Cairo, will be greatly enlarged, and that new offices will be established at Alexandria and Port Said. Mr. Ernest Stangen, general manager of the tourist department of the Hamburg-Amerika Line, is expected to arrive shortly.

div.p: The Land Bank of Egypt proposes, in the course of the month of April, to issue on the Paris market debentures to the amount of £2,500,000. div.head: MURDER IN CAIRO.
div.p: A cold-blooded murder was committed in Cairo on Sunday morning. About 8.30 a.m., as M. Egidio Gerosa, aged about 25, was on the point of entering the Catholic Church it the Mousky, ho received two shots in the back from the gun. He was immediately removed to the caracol in Ataba Khadra square, but shortly afterwards expired from the wounds he had received.

The murderer was arrested by the police men on duty outside the church, and was conveyed without showing any resistance to the samo caracol. The man's name is Fabio Ninci, and, like his victim, is of Italian nationality. It appears that he had some time ago been discharged from the service of tho Telephone Company, where he was employed as a wires-man. This discharge ho attributed toM.Gerosa, who was an electrician of the company, and it was to avenge himself that he had committed the deed. An enquiry has been opened by the Italian consular authorities in Cairo ; meantime, the murderer has been incarcerated in the central native prison. He will be sent to Ancona for trial Yesterday afternoon, at 4 o'olock, the funeral of the victim took place from the Italian Hospital At Abbassieh. The Italian Consul and Vicennial, Mr. StevensoD, manager, and the rest of the personnel of the Telephone Company were amongst the five hundred persons who formed tho funeral cortege. Great sympathy was evinced for the unfortunate engineer, and the funeral service at 8t Joseph's Church,Ismailia,was largely attended. The interment took place at the Catbolic Cemetery. It is rumoured that M. Gerosa's death the result of a plot among the workmen discharged by the Telephone Company, some of whom are said to be Anarchists,but- this rumour lacks confirmation at present

div.head: ALEXANDRIA ARCHÆOLOGICAL SOCIETY. EXCURSION TO ABOUKIR.
div.p: Yesterday, a large number of the members of Alexandria Archeological Society, accompanied by their families and a few invited friends, in all numbering probably over 150, took part in the first exouraion of the season arranged by the committee of the society. Alonkir was the chosen destination, and an inspection of the tesselated pavements of the supposed temple of Canopis, prior to their removal to the Alexandria Museum, the object of the visit. Special arrangements were made for the conveyance of the party by the 4.10 afternoon train from Sidi Gaber, and on the completion of the journey the train drew up on the line at the spot nearest to the Hike. This was a little awkward for the ladies and children, who found some difficulty in alighting from the carriages, but it was soon overcome by the help of their male companions. The afternoon was fine, and the heat was tempered by a cool breeze, rendering the walk through the fields of barley—which was in process of harvesting—a pleasant one. Arrived at the site of the temple, the company grouped themselves around a stone from which Dt,_ Breccia gave a short lectors descriptive of the history of the rains as far as it is known or can be conjectured. A great deal on this subject has already appeared in our columns, and only in the early part of this year we called attention to the necessity of steps being taken for the preservation of these interesting tessalated pavements. After the lecture and an inspection of the pavements and the The few granite columns visible, the company wended their way to Kharabia, where Prince Omar Toussonn had very kindly erected a tent, in which refresh meats were served, and greatly appreciated after the long and tiring walk. Before leaving the tent Mr. Ralli, as president of the Archeological Society, thanked Prince Omar Toussoun for his kindness in affording the party the facilities he had given, and Dr. Schiesa, on the part of the Alexandria Musuem, thanked Dr. Breooia for his interesting speech. A number of very interesting ratios were on view in some outbuildings of Prince Toussoun, and after inspecting these the company proceeded to Khabara station, whére they entrained at 7.30 for Alexandria. We may mention, as being in the party, Yacoub Pasha Artin, Sir Gerald Pitigerald, Judge Batcheller, Mr. and Mrs. Gould, Admiral Sir Massie and Lady Blomfield, Hon. Mrs. Hcpkinaon, Boron Alfred de Menasoe, Mr. Ssndara, Mr. and Mrs. Maoanlay, Mr. and Mme Girard, Baron von Humboldt Dtcbroe-der, Mme Constantine Sinadino, Mr. Ambroise Ralli, Mr. and Mrs. 8idney Oarver, Mrs. Borchgrevfak, Mr. and Mrs. Bourgeois.

div.head: ALEXANDRIA CONSERVATOIRE.
div.p: A very interesting concert was given by the Conservatoire of the People's University last night, and if such excellent programs are provided from time to time the subscribers will be doubled and trebled soon and a larger concert hall will have to be provided. We hear, however, that the new hall kindly provided by M. Aghion behind the French Consulate, is much more spacious than the University's lecture hall and also better ventilated. For want of space the choruses sung by the pupils were given in a room behind tho platform, the door between being left open. The effect was a very pleasing one and the choruses (a) Serenata Napoli tana, (b) Barcarole, by Dénia, were sung with ''attack'' and precision, the lights and.shades being well attended to. A young tenor, M. Papanti, sang, "Aprite," by Toeti, with expression and great tunefulness, and his voice has a future fa store tor him. The two pianoforte pupils were quite Aon de ligne. Miss Giglio's classical appreciation of her part in the Beethoven Quartott, fa which the was supported by the profwsors of the Conservatoire, Messrs. Lama, Cuirlo and Romeo, being remarkable for its thoughtfulness and good taste. Mile. Levi, too, absolutely astonished her audience by her brilliant passage playing in Lizst's Rhapsodie No. XIa. Mlle. Vente kindly took port in the programme and delighted everyone by the tinging of two songs, "Le Saüs," by Olagnier, and a charming romance written by the director artistique of the Conservatoire Professor Colella. Both songs were sung with great expression, and Mile. Verita's voice has in our opinion greatly improved in timbre and reserve since we have had the pleasure of hearing her. Last, but very far from least, came Mendelssohn's splendid Serenata, played famously well by Professor Colella, and he was accompanied by a small orchestra under the baton of Mr. Gianni Galletti, who also accompanied all the songs. We were glad to hear that during the concert the vice president, Lady Blomfield1 was promised £25 by a generous music-lover, who heard she was in need of funds to purchase a few instruments necessary for the orchestra now being formed. The organizers of the " Pavane, " i.e, the representation given for the Enfants trouvés at the Zizinia, have kindly promised to repeat their performance at popular prices in aid of the funds of the University and the Conseratoire
